facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 188 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 188 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal was by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 8, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1557 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 8 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1557 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered on November 7, 1962 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-This appeal raises

facts.text: West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949 (W.B. XXI of 1949) was enacted to provide for speedy trial of specified offenses.

anchor.surface_text: the proper construction of ss. 4 and 5 of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Act, 1949  W. B. XXI of 1949  to which we shall refer as the Act.

facts.text: Police filed a report before the Chief Presidency Magistrate at Calcutta in February 1958 charging ten accused persons including the appellant with offenses under s. 120B read with s. 409 and s. 477 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to the present appeal may now be stated. The police filed a report before the Chief Presidency Magistrate at Calcutta in February, 1958 charging ten accused persons including the appellant

facts.text: State Government issued order dated June 1, 1959 notified in the Official Gazette assigning the case to the Calcutta Additional Special Court under s. 4(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, by an order of the State Government dated June 1, 1959, notified in the official , Gazette the said case was assigned to the Calcutta Additional Special Court under s. 4  2  of the Act,

facts.text: On September 26, 1959, the Investigating Officer of the Enforcement Branch, Calcutta, filed a petition before the Special Judge praying to take cognizance and issue process against the accused.

anchor.surface_text: On September 26, 1959, the Investigating Officer of the Enforcement Branch, Calcutta, filed a petition before the Special judge praying that the judge might be pleased to take cognizance

facts.text: On September 26, 1959, the Additional Special Judge took cognizance of the offenses and issued notices to the accused persons fixing a date for appearance.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day  September 26, 1959 , the Additional Special judge took cognizance of the offenses and issued notices to the accused persons fixing a date for their appearance.

facts.text: Appellant made an application before the Special Judge stating that the initiation of proceedings by the petition of the Investigating Officer was not proper and legal.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this notice the appellant made an application before the Special judge stating that the initiation of the proceedings the petition of the Investigating Branch, Calcutta, was not proper

facts.text: Additional Special Judge rejected the appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Special judge rejected that petition.

facts.text: Appellant moved the Calcutta High Court in revision urging that the Special Judge could not take cognizance on the complaint of the police officer and lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court of Calcutta in revision, urging the same ground, namely, that the Special judge could not take cognizance of the offence on the or complaint

facts.text: Two earlier decisions of the Calcutta High Court held that Special Judge acquires jurisdiction only after complying with s.190(1) CrPC otherwise than on police report.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, it is necessary to mention that in two earlier decisions of the Calcutta High Court the view had been held that a Special judge did not acquire jurisdiction

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court referred the matter to Full Bench doubting correctness of earlier decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench before which the revision of the present appellant came on for disposal entertained doubts about the correctness of these two earlier decisions

facts.text: Full Bench questions: Whether Special Judge needs petition/complaint for cognizance or takes cognizance upon receiving notification and records and applying mind.

anchor.surface_text: The questions referred were Does the Special Judge appointed under the WestBengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Act, 1949, to whom a case has been allotted

facts.text: Full Bench by majority held Special Court takes cognizance when receives Government notification and records, applies mind to facts and takes steps.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the Full Bench by a majority answered questions in the following terms A Special Court is said to have taken cognizance when on receiving the Government Notification

facts.text: Full Bench held earlier decisions incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: The second question was answered by saying that the earlier decisions referred to were incorrect.

facts.text: West Bengal Legislature enacted Act XXIV of 1960 amending s.5 of the Act before Full Bench hearing.

anchor.surface_text: After the order of reference to the Full Bench and before the hearing of the reference, the West Bengal Legislature enacted Act XXIV of 1960

facts.text: Full Bench held amendment of 1960 does not invalidate proceedings already taken as no specific provision to that effect.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges observed that though the amendment being in relation to a matter of procedure might ordinarily apply to pending proceedings as well it did not however

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed the appellant's revision petition following Full Bench opinion.

anchor.surface_text: Following the opinion expressed by the Full Bench the revision petition file by the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who comes here by the special leave contests the correctness of the answer of the Full Bench

facts.text: Amendments were made to the June 1, 1959 notification but nothing turns on them.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime later amendments were made to this Notification but nothing turns on them.

facts.text: K. Chakravarti, Amiyalal Chatterjee and P.K. Mukherjee appeared for the Appellant.

anchor.surface_text: K. Chakravarti, Amiyalal Chatterjee and P.K. Mukherjee for the Appellant. Sen, P. K. Chatterjee and P. K. Bose, for the Respondents.

facts.text: Sen, P. K. Chatterjee and P. K. Bose appeared for the Respondents.

anchor.surface_text: K. Chakravarti, Amiyalal Chatterjee and P.K. Mukherjee for the Appellant. Sen, P. K. Chatterjee and P. K. Bose, for the Respondents.

facts.text: State Government constitutes Special Courts by notification under Section 2 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 empowers the State Government to constitute by notification in the Official Gazette one or more special courts.

issues.text: Does the Special Judge appointed under the WestBengal Criminal Law Amendment Special Courts Act, 1949, to whom a case has been allotted by notification u s 4 2 of the Act need a petition of complaint for taking cognizance of the case or does he take cognizance when on receiving the Government notification and the record of charge from the court of the Magistrate, he applies his mind to the facts of the case ?

anchor.surface_text: The questions referred were Does the Special Judge appointed under the WestBengal Criminal Law Amendment Special Courts Act, 1949, to whom a case has been allotted by notification u s 4 2 of the Act need a petition of complaint for taking cognizance of the case or does he take cognizance when on receiving the Government notification and the record of charge from the court of the Magistrate,

issues.text: whether [the two earlier decisions of the Calcutta High Court] had been correctly decided.

anchor.surface_text: There was a second question which specifically referred to the two earlier decisions and raised a query as to whether they had been correctly decided.

issues.text: the main question that arises in the case as regards the jurisdiction of the Special judge to take cognizance of an offence without the procedure prescribed by s. 190 1 being complied with.

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up for consideration the main question that arises in the case as regards the jurisdiction of the Special judge to take cognizance of an offence without the procedure prescribed by s. 190 1 being complied with.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: indefinite import, and is number perhaps always used in exactly the same sense. As observed in Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty 3 , taking comp

arguments.court_reasoning: Not purporting to be declaratory; effects change prospectively; no invalidation of prior valid proceedings.

holdings.text: The judge of the Special Court appointed under s. 2 of the Act is not within the class of Magistrates designated by s. 190(1) and hence there can be no question of such a judge having to comply with its requirements before he can take cognizance of an offence.

anchor.surface_text: It should be noted that the application of this section is limited to Presidency Magistrates, District Magistrates, Sub divisional Magistrates and other Magistrates specially empowered in that behalf and it is common ground that the judge of the Special Court appointed under s. 2 of the Act is not within the class of Magistrates designated by s. 190 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.190(1) expressly limited to specified Magistrates; Special Judge excluded by textual reading.

holdings.text: s.5(1) of the Act expressly overrides s.193(1) CrPC; no committal order required despite Special Court being 'deemed' Court of Session under s.5(2).

anchor.surface_text: If the special court is deemed to be a court of session, a doubt might arise as to whether the provision in s. 193 1 of the Code is or is not inconsistent with the Act vide s. 5 2 of the Act , and hence to clear the position s. 5 1 enacts, so to say, that notwithstanding that a special court is deemed to be court of session, section 193 1 does not apply to it

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(1) provides for cognizance without committal; 'deemed' vests powers with modifications, harmonious construction.

holdings.text: No additional material beyond s.4(2) allotment order and case records is required for Special Court to take cognizance; jurisdiction vests upon receipt and application of mind by issuing notice etc.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us therefore that as soon as a special judge receives the orders of allotment of the case passed by the State Government it becomes vested with jurisdiction to try the case and when it receives the record from the Government it can apply its mind and issue notice to the accused and thus start the trial of the proceedings assigned to it by the State Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cognizance means judicial notice upon applying mind; no statutory or general requirement for specific material beyond allotment records; confirms Bhajahari interpretation.

holdings.text: s.529 CrPC inapplicable to Special Judge as cognizance not taken under s.190(1)(a) or (b).

anchor.surface_text: the provision which is applicable to Magistrates designated in s. 190 1 is not applicable to the special judge who does not take cognizance in that manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Curative provision limited to Magistrates under s.190; Special Judge outside scope.

holdings.text: Words 'otherwise than on a police report' in s.5(1) merely exclude s.251A CrPC procedure; no further significance.

anchor.surface_text: Some little point was made of the words otherwise than on a police report occuring at the end of s. 5 1 of the Act. In our opinion, nothing turns on them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical amendment post-1955 CrPC change to ensure inapplicability of new police report procedure.

holdings.text: 1960 Amending Act not declaratory; effects prospective change without invalidating prior valid proceedings under original s.5(1).

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act does not purport to be declaratory but seeks in terms to carry out an amendment, in other words, to effect a change. The mere fact that the change effected conforms to a particular interpretation which the words which previously existed might bear

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express retrospective words; procedural amendments apply prospectively absent specific invalidation provision; alignment with one interpretation insufficient for declaratory effect.

precedents.cited_proposition: Jurisdiction of the special court arises upon notification under s. 4(2) distributing the case, and cognizance is taken upon receipt of record and taking steps in aid of progress
precedents.cited_holding: The crucial date for determining jurisdiction is when the court receives the record, takes cognizance, and takes a step in aid of progress; jurisdiction arises from notification giving names and charges.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us therefore that as soon as a special judge receives the orders of allotment of the case passed by the State Government it becomes vested with jurisdiction to try the case and when it receives the record from the Government it can apply its mind and issue notice to the accused and thus start the trial of the proceedings assigned to it by the State Government.
